headline: Boeing Is Reportedly Working on 737 Max Successor. Here’s Why That Matters.
summary: Boeing has reportedly started working on a next-generation single-aisle aircraft that could eventually succeed the 737 Max, as the plane maker looks to regain business lost to rival Airbus after a spate of quality problems in recent years.

raw.headline: Boeing Is Reportedly Working on 737 Max Successor. Here’s Why That Matters.

headline: Boeing focuses on recovery, but watching market for new single-aisle jet
summary: SEATTLE (Reuters) -Boeing said it is focused on the company's recovery, amid news reports of the U.S. planemaker developing a new single-aisle jet to succeed its best-selling jet, the 737 MAX.  “Our teams continue to be focused on our recovery plan, including delivering on our existing backlog of nearly 6,000 commercial airplanes and certifying the new 737-7, 737-10 and 777-9 models," Boeing spokesperson Ryan Cudney said in an email.  Boeing's commercial airplane division has endured a series of crises in recent years, including in 2024 a mid-air accident of a new 737 MAX and a 53-day-long strike that shut down most of its jet production.

raw.headline: Boeing focuses on recovery, but watching market for new single-aisle jet

Boeing's commercial airplane division has endured a series of crises in recent years, including in 2024 a mid-air accident of a new 737 MAX and a 53-day-long strike that shut down most of its jet production.

headline: BAE Systems and Forterra join forces to develop autonomous Armored Multi-Purpose Vehicle prototype
summary: BAE Systems (LON: BA) and Forterra today announced they are collaborating to rapidly prototype an autonomous Armored Multi-Purpose Vehicle (AMPV). This is the first industry partnership BAE Systems has established as part of the vehicle's capability kit series announced last month.

headline: Boeing in early stages of developing 737 MAX replacement, WSJ reports
summary: STORY: Boeing is reportedly in the early stages of developing a new single-aisle airplane that would eventually replace the 737 MAX.The Wall Street Journal reported the development on Monday, citing people familiar with the matter.Reuters could not immediately confirm the report.And Boeing did not respond to a Reuters' request for comment.The 737 MAX entered service in 2017 but was grounded globally in 2019 after two fatal crashes killed 346 people.The incidents slashed Boeing's profits and triggered lawsuits, investigations, and a criminal probe.The Federal Aviation Administration lifted the grounding order in 2020 during the pandemic.Last Friday, the FAA said it would allow the planemaker to issue airworthiness certificates for some 737 MAX jets, starting this week.According to the Wall Street Journal report, Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg met with officials from Rolls-Royce Holdings in the UK earlier this year to discuss a new engine for the aircraft.Rolls-Royce declined to comment on Monday's report. Boeing also still faces regulatory scrutiny.Last year, the FAA imposed a production cap of 38 per month for 737 MAX planes.That was after a mid-air cabin panel blowout on a new Alaska Airlines jet, which was later found to be missing four bolts.That incident led the U.S. Justice Department, under former President Joe Biden, to open a criminal investigation.

raw.headline: Boeing in early stages of developing 737 MAX replacement, WSJ reports
raw.summary: STORY: Boeing is reportedly in the early stages of developing a new single-aisle airplane that would eventually replace the 737 MAX.The Wall Street Journal reported the development on Monday, citing people familiar with the matter.Reuters could not immediately confirm the report.And Boeing did not respond to a Reuters' request for comment.The 737 MAX entered service in 2017 but was grounded globally in 2019 after two fatal crashes killed 346 people.The incidents slashed Boeing's profits and triggered lawsuits, investigations, and a criminal probe.The Federal Aviation Administration lifted the grounding order in 2020 during the pandemic.Last Friday, the FAA said it would allow the planemaker to issue airworthiness certificates for some 737 MAX jets, starting this week.According to the Wall Street Journal report, Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg met with officials from Rolls-Royce Holdings in the UK earlier this year to discuss a new engine for the aircraft.Rolls-Royce declined to comment on Monday's report. Boeing also still faces regulatory scrutiny.Last year, the FAA imposed a production cap of 38 per month for 737 MAX planes.That was after a mid-air cabin panel blowout on a new Alaska Airlines jet, which was later found to be missing four bolts.That incident led the U.S. Justice Department, under former President Joe Biden, to open a criminal investigation.
